job_title: Registered Nurse, CVICU in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Aaron Henry, our manager in CVICU, is one of the best bosses I have ever had the pleasure of working with. He cares about each of his staff, and tries his best to accomdate when able.
- Wonderful place to obtain CVICU experience (ECMO, LVAD, IABP, etc...)
cons:
- Wellstar has mandated all staff receive the Covid-19 vaccine or be terminated
- Many of the nurses in the unit remind me of high school girls, because there is so much gossip, and they will throw tantrums if they don't get their way.
- Pay is mediocre compared to other Atlanta hospitals.
- The Cardiothoracic Surgeons (Dr. Luu; Dr. Burke; Dr. Myung) are hands-off, so we communicate almost exclusively with their PA's and NP's. 
- Their (CT Surgeons) PA's and NP's are also demeaning and talk down to new staff.
- Poor interprofessional communcation between the CT surgeons, Critical Care, and Heart Failure teams; which often results in the nurse serving as the messenger between them.
- Grossly understaffed
- There is borderline (arguably actual) discrimination against those who choose not to be vaccinated, regardless of legitamate reasons.

review_title: They only repaid half the staff for the pandemic loss
pros: A job is the only pro
cons:
Many of our hours were cut during the start of covid an many months after. Some people were forced to take their pto (which was earned from coming to work and there for vacations and sick days) to keep their lights on. Some staff did not have to take their pto and just suffered being short money.
Wellstar came out this month and gave the people who did not take their pto money for their income shortage over the time, yet did not reimburse those who used their pto! People spent 100 hours of their pto to make ends meet and instead of offering it back to them they were looked over! 
The people who didn’t take their pto still have their vacation time to take and were paid directly from wellstar for the lost hours!
Shame on wellstar for taking advantage of staff who did nothing but work and now cannot take off work for vacations that are well deserved because they spent their pto to feed their family’s when you turned around and gave the money to people who now can take vacations and got the money lost back!
Greedy company !
Now we’re getting hours cut again: we don’t know whether to take our pto or go without for you to pay us later!

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Douglasville, GA
pros:
Shift Differential ( $1.50/weekends, $1.75/ 3rd shift night)
Great Security at most of of the hospitals.
Many opportunities to interact with patients. If you are looking for exposure to various mental health diagnosis, this offers that. Everyday is a new experience. There are many opportunities of down time where you can learn more about your patients on a personal level or access the many online trainings Wellstar offers. They have a decent EAP program and gym program. They have many work life balance programs but not many chances to use them.  Many opportunities for overtime! ( if you don't work at Douglas as a MHA)
Management does listen to concerns, they may take a while to get addressed but they eventually do.
cons:
Low pay (Range from $12 - $16 an hour)
Poor Benefits
 As mental health associate, there are not many areas for career development. This is a great entry level position to get experience but unfortunately there are no other positions to grow into unless you get your LPC,LSCW, etc or switch to nursing. The MHA position varies at different hospitals.  Unfortunately at Douglas, the manager does not allow the staff to work at other hospitals or even other floors when there is a need. This means limited overtime and does not allow the employees to experience other hospitals/units. This ultimately limits employees from gaining useful experiences from other hospitals or units that may be beneficial.

pros: The benefits are amazing. Health insurance, life insurance,dental, and other benefits are very affordable.
cons: Very high turn overs. Poor structure and boundaries amongst the employees and mangers. The call out/ tardy policy is ridiculous. If you are not admitted to a hospital, Calling out and leaving early will counted against you with a doctors note. If you are in a position to serve employees and patients, expect the worst from your fellow coworkers. I have regularly  experienced nasty attitudes, rude comments, and complaints from my coworkers. They will make the most ridiculous requests and expect you to do it. If you do not oblige, expect an email to go to your manager. The managers usually will not your side. Even if the request is something you have no control or authority to satisfy their request. They will do their best to underpay you. Before I was rehired, I have applied for a position  at a higher rate and was denied it but was hired on for a different position at a lower rate and I still end up doing the position I originally applied for a few days out of the week and was not properly compensatedas stated in their policies.From my experience , If you are injured on the job and return with limitations, the managers do not abide by your limitations. Even if you bring it to their attention multiple times, they just brush you off.

pros: The only pros of working for this organization were the pros of my job before we were acquired by Wellstar. The team and the physicians were the only pro. Benefits are only good in a major emergency.
cons: Upper management is incompetent in every sense of the word. They have no idea what it actually takes to run a practice. Practice managers and DPO's are not held accountable for their incompetency and unjust behavior. They are living, breathing examples of lies and deception. This organization prides themselves on trust and demands trust from its employees, but lacks the basic moral values that life requires to gain trust. The Human Resources department is useless and unresponsive. They do not support employees nor do they take the time to even respond to serious complaints from the people who keep their practices and hospitals running. They support the hierarchy before the truth, always. Regardless of evidence and facts. The pay rate is way below market value. Their practices are full of dedicated, talented, caring and hardworking employees and physicians who genuinely care about the well-being of patients. Wellstar absolutely does not care about the voice of the employee, the physician or the patient. They are nothing but a money hungry machine and a snake pit.

job_title: Nursing Care Associate in Marietta, GA
pros: Great coworkers, decent pay, good benefits.
cons: High tech-to-patient ratio and nurse-to-patient ratio. Techs are given more than10 patients each and expected to still be able to keep up with all of the patients' needs, while often the other tech or the assigned nurse is so busy themselves they can offer no assistance. Bed control does not seem to understand how it stresses an entire unit to receive 4 new patients within thirty minutes of each other (and understaffed unit, might I add). Nursing management doesn't seem to understand patient needs do not diminish at night and night shift employees are even more overworked than daytime associates. Management does NOT give consideration to patient acuity when making assignments. A nurse may have 1 patient who needs constant, q15 minute manual bladder irrigation and that nurse still receives another 5-6 patients along with it. Management likes to give the illusion of wanting to consider nurses' and staff input but never actually listens. Run as fast as you can away from this health system.

pros:

cons:
The new benefits in 2018 are a joke. Matching 1/4 percent on 403b for each percent we put in.  They added a pension plan..but we all know how quickly that money can leave. 
Benefits went to a High Deductible and HSA card program. I work for a hospital and my insurance covers less of the business we are actually in.

pros: There are competitive rates here

review_title: Easy to get a job for new grad RN
pros: Great people work for Wellstar . The company has grown exponentially overnight. Job security is a plus. Onsite gym and concierge. Onsite Bistro and Starbucks.
cons: Growth too fast without planning or quality processes in place. Reactionary upper management to initiate new processes immediately. Encouraged to overhire new grad nurses without concern for having skill mix or proper infrastructure in place to train and mentor new grads. Large sign on bonuses offered to new grads. Not competitive with pay rates for experienced nurses. High out of pocket deductible for top and middle insurance plans. Human Resources really believes that they are competing with other area hospitals. Frequent turnover in manager level and Director positions. Advertising work life balance but that is non existent. Expect to be on call 24/7. Did not give employees who were affected by snow storm and stayed at the hospital inclement weather pay. Only offered one meal ticket to those that stayed overnight to work and nothing to employees that risked their life to get to work. Employees slept on cots in the Fitness center. Bottom line is saving a dime while spending a dollar with this executive top heavy organization. Nurses week eliminated and now called Hospital week. How cheap can you be?

review_title: RUN! Zero support from management or HR

cons: Any, and Everything else encountered

review_title: Very poor treatment of long term employees
pros: It is a place to work
cons: No work-life balance.  Bonuses to regular employees are based on customer service in the emergency department which the other departments have no control over.  Bonus is supposedly a max of $750 but all system employees are receiving $84 for the yearly bonus, Cobb hospital employees get $64, Douglas employees get $300, not exactly fair especially when upper management gets thousands in bonuses.  The benefits are a joke, very expensive and terrible service.  The IT department in particular is a nightmare.  Employees are resigning on a weekly basis and no one cares.  Going to H.R. is a sure way to get targeted and there are no employee advocates.  Employee surveys are sent out and the results speak volumes but management just puts teams in a room and berates them for the poor scores.  Been there 12 years and it is worse now than I have ever seen by far.  No oversight anywhere.  The foxes run the hen house.

pros: If you are a drug addict, lazy, real crazy, or pretend crazy, you will never get fired no matter how bad you behave.
cons:
1) No opportunity for advancement unless you know someone, and then in that case they will create a position for that person. All the while stating they have no money in the budget for supplies, extra much needed staff, a raise, continued learning, or a holiday luncheon.
2) Impossible to fire staff.  Allows lazy workers to not work but expects the good workers to pick up the slack.
3) Management team falsifies reports to the executive team; unsure how far up the chain the lies are perpetrated.
4) Makes the new hires take a personality test, which actually filled my office with a bunch of people that are very similar; they're all crazy.
5) The management team has created an atmosphere of fear and confusion.
6) Health benefits are not good; that includes the insurance before the implementation of the ACA law and after. 
7) The culture is horrible.  Many employees are rude.  There is a lot of backstabbing and in-fighting.

review_title: Looking for a progressive organization? Look elsewhere.
pros: If you know how to fall in line, don't question anything, play c suite politics, don't really care about being progressive in business or patient care, you are welcomed here. As long as they continue to physically dominate the market, WellStar will be a stable company.
cons: If you have drive and intelligence, you will not stay long. Intelligent and driven people find this organization stifling and are generally made targets at some point during their employment as they offer up new ideas, rejecting the status quo and challenging management in an effort to bring innovation. Your innovative ideas and varied opinions are not welcomed.

pros: Non-profit company with longevity. Good perks and retirement plan.
cons: Low pay. Long commute from where I live. Rural hospital in Griffin needs to be replaced with a new modern hospital. The hospital is old, small, limited in space and bathrooms, crowded hallways, semi-private patient rooms, tiny staff office with no staff refrigerator, limited computers for documentation, dirty, racial and cultural insensitivity among staff, 30 minutes drive if you have to go Jackson facility, hourly pay rather than salary, lean staff, old and outdated equipment. This hospital is not competitive with the other and much nicer surroundings hospitals in the area. I am desperately seeking transfer to a closer facility.

pros: Hours, patients, vacation allotted, PRN staff were very nice

review_title: Great depending on who your manager is

review_title: They take care of the patients, but not the professionals who work there.

Senior management response to minor and major problems is knee-jerk;  the mantra is "just keep it out of the media." Resources are wasted by hiring consultants to tell them what their well-educated employees have already said.  The "family friendly/ Working Mother culture is not carried through the workplace.  I had a manager who told me, essentially, to get a nanny for my school age children because "that's what I did."  Upper level management will stab you in the back if it makes them look good.

pros:
Work life balance and great patients
Nice new facilities

great Physicians and hard working staff!

Very racist corporation that hides behind convoluted guidelines they do not follow. They tolerate harassment in the work place and lack diversity in management and leadership. Directors are shady and HR is not monitoring the lack of legality around terminations.

Pay is ridiculously low and their equity compensations are Not comparable to metro Atlanta. 

Ignorant leadership. Why do you hire Directors who have no experience in the field they govern?

Good ole boy system. Might as well be 1969 instead of 2019.

review_title: Avoid WellStar if you're able.....if not, its an ok company to work for short-term. Best of luck.

pros: Patients love you because you are always there when they call. If you need extra money you can call and pick up on your off days.

Basically expect to work the hardest and looked down  upon the most as well as being paid the least.

review_title: I have worked for WellStar for 9 years and love the professional, but fun atmosphere.

cons: Long hiring process even if working within the system.  Transfers to other departments take a very long time to process.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Atlanta, GA
pros: It's a stable employer, layoffs are rare, has a pension plan.
cons: It's a job, but forget about a career, advancement doesn't happen.  Promotions, don't expect much, even less annually than inflation. Negotiate every dime you can coming in the door because you'll be there forever.  Also benefits are not that great when it comes to insurance.  401K (403b actually) matching is pathetic.  "Bonuses" are paid out.  Last year was enough for a tank of gas.

pros:
*Wellstar in constantly growing and this creates lots of opportunity.

*Wellstar is a financially stable company that has deep roots in the community it serves.
cons:
*Expensive health insurance. Supposedly competitive with other Atlanta hospitals but considering

 employees are basically covered to see physicians that are employees of Wellstar it is sort of a rip 

off.

* Upper and middle management has not been responsive to concerns of unsafe staffing made by

 several units.

* Work Life balance is difficult to achieve. They are constantly asking if you will changes shifts and

 calling staff off at the last minute. It is very commom to be placed on call at these hospitals without 

any call pay reimbursement. As a single mom, it makes it very difficult to obtain child care.

review_title: Family friendly benefits, free concierge services, generous paid time off, training and development, flexibie work

cons: Very long shifts - 10.5 hours. Shifts can begin as early as 4:45am and end as late as 8pm. Not a lot of safety precautions concerning burns on hands from constantly handling hot containers and serving utensils left under heat lamps for hours. Very fast paced. 30 minute lunch break, usually after all the food being served is gone. Plan on bringing your own lunch so you don't end up eating crackers or cereal. You'll need the energy.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Roswell, GA
pros: Doctors in our office care not only for their patients but their staff too.  Very respective to all that enters these doors

pros: I have been working for WELLSTAR for the past 8 yrs and I have had good and bad experiences. Working as a floor nurse is a difficult profession regardless of the employer.  While I enjoyed

review_title: LPN at Cobb County Adult Detention

cons: Don't care about their employees. You get treated as if you're disposable no matter if you work hard or not. A lot of favoritism towards older staff. Upper management very unprofessional and ghetto. Some HR reps aren't even great resources to go to for issues because they are in the mix with the bad managers. I will NEVER work for this system again!

pros: Loved the actual work I completed many innovative projects that helped the Patients & Providers.
cons: Too much favoritism. When I left 1 day short of my 2 week notice Wellstar kept a weeks worth of PTO & didn't pay me for my last week I worked.

review_title: A dominating presence in the community but sorely lacking when it comes to employee engagement.
pros: Health Place and employee perks. Wellstar offers discounts for a bevy of retail, restaurant, and   travel.
cons: Non-competitive pay. Pay scale is not designed to recruit or retain quality employees.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Marietta, GA
pros: Purchasing Power, payroll deduction, 401K
cons: Short-staffed, quotas to be met which decrease the quality of care to the patient,  constantly being asked to do surveys, bonuses formulated to where they are unattainable, poor benefits/costs for the size of company, pay not comparable to other healthcare systems in the area, protocols/policies constantly changing, poor raises.

review_title: Your work experience will differ like night and day depending on your department
pros:
In certain departments, the atmopshere is very laid back. You can come in when you like and leave when your done as long as you meet your hourly commitment. In other departments they watch you're clock in times like a hawk

There are some nice benefits like the concierge but if your salary sucks then you can't even really afford to use them. 

You get about a month of PTO a year, even as a new employee. But each department has different PTO policies so even if you have it you may not be able to use it. 

It's safe to say that every Pro is followed by a Con. There aren't any out and out Pros to working for WellStar except maybe name recognition on your resume.
cons:
Work-life balance, while it may be a goal of the company, is not possible for 36 hour employees. Working 3, 12 hour shifts a week means you literally lose 3 days out of your week. While that does leaves you  with 4 days off a week, they are often scattered and more needed for recovery rather than enjoying yourself or getting personal things done.

Not very autonomous, this is a big one for me. I have to be trusted to do my job but micromanaging  prevails at WellStar. 

Retail like atmosphere for hourly employees. It's hard to feel as though you hold a professional position when you're treated like a waste of payroll. 

Every job has a big pay range i.e. $15 - $25 an hour. The  hourly rate most likely to be offered will be on the lower range. HR employees are paid a pretty large salary and are surprisingly not paid commissions. But part of  their yearly bonus depends on how under budget they keep new hires. So don't expect much bargaining room even if it is there.

review_title: Poor culture. Major problems that continue to go unaddressed
pros: Good location in NW Marietta
cons: Poor Culture. Lack of opportunities. Cronyism. Lack of equal visibility on projects for all employees. Education only available for cronies. Abusive middle management. HR that does nothing to prevent injustices against employees by middle management. Middle management not required to provide legitimate documentation of incidences. Retribution is rampant in Administrative offices. Repressive work environment. Poor vacation - "3 weeks", 6 of which are National Holidays with offices closed, remaining 9 days are personal, sick & vacation days. Hospital employees are far happier than administrative employees or so it seems - attribute to satisfaction of caring for patients & patient genuine gratitude.

cons:
-They do not competitively pay. 
-They very much low-ball the nurses.  
-They unfairly offer raises to specialty areas but not for other areas that truly work very hard and in very difficult circumstances, mainly the med surg areas (7G W,N,S and 4 W,S).  
-They keep incompetent management and lose valuable nurses due to this poor management being in those roles. 
-They refuse to eliminate semi-private rooms which is such an old and dated thing but just shows the gross greedy spirit of the entity, they only want what makes more money not what's best for staff and patients.
- It is not uncommon for nurses in med/surg areas to have 6 patients every day and for the resource/charge nurses to carry a full team along with all the charge duties. 
-Relief charge nurses get only 0.50/hour extra, to manage a very difficult role! That's only  $6.00 for the whole day to run a floor!!! RIDICULOUS!!!

review_title: Low Pay, Health Insurance Sucked, No support from Management
job_title: Front Desk Specialist in Marietta, GA
pros: Most offices have friendly employees, Flexibility to make your own schedule as long as your scheduling requirements are met
cons: Low pay, Health Insurance extremely high, you’re practically working to pay insurance. Float pool requirements are unrealistic for a position that’s supposedly PRN. I had to work 6 days a month, one weekend day a month at the urgent care, one major holiday a year and my schedule had to be set 8 weeks in advance, I couldnt pick which office I wanted to go to so essentially I could be scheduled to work extremely far from home with no mileage reimbursement. The office needs aren’t verified so plenty of time I’ve shown up to a fully staffed office that don’t need additional help just to be rerouted to another office and not paid for mileage. The way they act like they are reimbursing you is to say you get paid for the time you clocked in and drive time to the next office. Well if I worked at the assigned office I would still get paid for the same time, save gas and have less mileage in my car. Not a even exchange. If  I showed up to a office that didn’t need me there was no option to go home. I had to wait to get a call back from scheduling to tell me where to go next. A few times there weren’t any other assignments available so I would only get paid for the hour that I sat waiting for scheduling to call me back. Reminder: I wasted gas and mileage driving to work that day. A lot of times I arrived at offices that had me scheduling appointments all day because the regular staff didn’t want to. We held monthly meetings for our department but nothing would get corrected after our complaints were voiced. During the holidays it was suggested that we bring a pot luck meanwhile all other departments went into there petty cash to buy gifts or at least lunch for their employees. Last but not least no annual raises or monthly incentives for meeting goal

review_title: DO NOT WORK HERE IN PATIENT SERVICES (RN, NP, TECH, MD)
pros: Variety of areas to work in
cons: Horrible management, both on the unit level and above. Compensation not great for new employees, raises are very minimal, time-off policies and late/absence policies are excessive; expectations for healthcare staff are ridiculous when compared to the amount of time provided and corresponding compensation. There is a horrible lack of teamwork, petty "cliques" form within units, and management singles out specific people for reprimanding, as well as those who receive praise. Management definitely shows favoritism, and lacks empathy with their staff. The benefits starting in 2014 are HORRIBLE. Worst health insurance I have ever had; extremely limited choice of providers, exorbitant costs for any doctor visits. I have seen both management and staff employees show and make jokes concerning racism, sexism, lack of tolerance for minority groups, lack of support for those with different sexual orientations, and lack of support for those with differing political and religious beliefs. Staff attitudes are very right-wing, conservative, highly religious, and staff do not keep these opinions to themselves. If you don't fit into this specific group, you will be ostracized by your fellow coworkers. WellStar does NOT promote diversity in any way possible. Staff members are encouraged to "tell" on each other, instead of handling matters directly between themselves. Upper level management discuss and share specific issues relating to specific staff members with other staff members who are completely not involved in the issues at hand. I've never seen a place that gossips so incredibly much. You do not have a private personal life while working here; everyone will want to know your business, and they will share it with everyone on the unit.
